nodes.title: CLIP Text Encode (Positive Prompt)
widgets_values: A cinematic shot following a rugged car as it navigates down a steep, muddy riverbank. The car's iconic World Rally Blue paint is splattered with mud, while its gold-finished alloy wheels dig into the soft earth. Water droplets and mud particles spray dramatically in slow motion as all four wheels power through the terrain. Lush, overgrown grass and wild vegetation frame both sides of the makeshift track, swaying in the wind. The late afternoon sunlight filters through a light mist, creating atmospheric rays that catch the flying mud particles.

nodes.title: CLIP Text Encode (Negative Prompt)
widgets_values: shaky, glitchy, low quality, worst quality, deformed, distorted, disfigured, motion smear, motion artifacts, fused fingers, bad anatomy, weird hand, ugly

Forward Sampler

* Gamma controls the amount of noise that's injected into unsampling.

This can help if you're trying to make a very large shift away from the input video.

If used I suggest end_step = total_steps/2 and gamma = 0.5, with linear_decrease

This can help decrease the exact adherence to the input video.


* Order

Order is the amount of inner steps to do which could increase the information gathered from the input video.

Currently gamma > 0 and Second Order do not work well together.

Reverse Sampling

* eta 

Controls how strong the input video latents influence the sampling

This is an alternative to attention injection, but can also be used in conjunction

If the Forward Sampler has "First" order, this can not use "Second" order and attention injections since the second order attentions were not unsampled.
Second will adhere to original details more

The woman's eyes jarringly flicker open, her blue irises spasmodically twitching as her gaze wildly darts around, her eyelids convulsively fluttering and casting erratic, distorted shadows on her cheeks. Her short, yellow hair appears to writhe and twist around her face, with the pink, spiked headpiece flashing in a dizzying, staccato rhythm, as if reflecting the chaotic, discordant lighting. The camera shudders and lurches in, its zoom jerky and unsteady, capturing the woman's face in a grotesque, exaggerated close-up, as the colorful, abstract swirl pattern in the background distorts and blurs in a maddening, kaleidoscopic whirl. The shot is frenetic, with the camera wildly panning and tilting, as if struggling to focus on the woman's face, which is bathed in harsh, clashing light, with shades of green, blue, and pink clashing and pulsating in a nauseating, disorienting display.

You are an expert cinematic director with many award winning movies, When writing prompts based on the user input, focus on detailed, chronological descriptions of actions and scenes. Include specific movements, appearances, camera angles, and environmental details - all in a single flowing paragraph. Start directly with the action, and keep descriptions literal and precise. Think like a cinematographer describing a shot list. Keep within 200 words. For best results, build your prompts using this structure:

Start with main action in a single sentence
Add specific details about movements and gestures
Describe character/object appearances precisely
Include background and environment details
Specify camera angles and movements
Describe lighting and colors
Note any changes or sudden events

Do not exceed the 150 word limit!

Image Injection

Replaces or inserts the image latent into the video latent.

When insert is Off, the image latent replaces the video latent.

When insert is On, the image latent is inserted into the video latents, extending the length of the video.

Note that latents are technically 8 frames long, but your image latent is only 1 frame, so this could cause issues if you replace/insert in the middle of the video.

Attention Injection

Controls how much of the unsampled attention is injected into the sampling. 

Increasing this will increase adherence to the input video.

You can save as much attention as you like, and then choose how much to inject here.

Blocks refer to the LTX Model's block to save/inject on.

Injecting too much may mean that if you are using an input image, the model has too much style information from the input video and disregards the input image.

The woman's eyes slowly open, her blue irises locking onto the camera as her gaze lowers, her eyelids casting a subtle shadow on her cheeks. Her short, yellow hair frames her face, with the pink, spiked headpiece glinting in the light. The camera zooms in on her face, capturing the serene yet melancholic expression, as the colorful, abstract swirl pattern in the background blurs slightly. The shot is static, with no pan or tilt, focusing on the woman's face, illuminated by soft, vibrant light, with shades of green, blue, and pink reflecting off her fair skin.

A digital painting of a woman with short, yellow hair and a pink, spiked headpiece. She has fair skin, blue eyes, and is lying on her back with her head tilted upwards. Her expression is serene and slightly melancholic. The background is a colorful, abstract swirl pattern in shades of green, blue, and pink. The style is hyper-realistic with a focus on vibrant colors and intricate details. The woman is positioned in the center of the image, facing the viewer., bizarre editorial fashion model opening her eyes and lowering her gaze to the camera, zoom-in, no-pan-x, no-pan-y

Create a Negative Prompt (200 words max) from a Positive Prompt:

In general, the idea is to take the input and describe the opposite. Sometimes this might mean your output negative prompt is actually describing smooth motion, but often not. Below are some examples and guidelines.

Motion Corruption:


Convert each movement into an opposite; smooth motions become jerky and vice versa
Make body parts move undesirably (i.e. opposite) e.g. independently and unnaturally
Add glitch-like interruptions to every gesture if the input text is smooth, or vice versa as required
Modify the desired speed to its opposite e.g. Insert random speed changes and reverse motions 
Try to ascertain how things should move from the input description and generally describe the opposite e.g. Make limbs stretch and distort during movement


Camera Destruction:


Add aggressive shaking and spinning
Include random Dutch angles
Make camera clip through subjects
Create nauseating perspective shifts
Take note of anything stylistic and describe the opposite (e.g. sometimes we may be dealing with photorealism and want to thus describe animation, or vice versa)


Writing Process:


Take each positive action and immediately corrupt it
Example: "graceful spin" → "spasmodic twisting with body parts rotating at different speeds"
Layer multiple motion problems simultaneously
Connect corrupted movements with chaotic camera work
Ensure every action breaks physics or human anatomy


Formatting:


Write as one flowing paragraph
Focus on active, real-time destruction of movement
Build intensity by layering multiple distortions
Make every motion as uncomfortable as possible
Keep camera work fighting against the main action

Remember: Take what's meant to look good and make it look broken, glitchy, and physically impossible. Focus on corrupting the specific movements mentioned in the positive prompt rather than adding unrelated chaos.

Camera options:

Zoom: in, no, out
PanX: left, no, right
PanY: up, no, down
Help the LLM a bit with vague/important things as you see fit; or don't

nodes.title: Text Guidance
widgets_values: bizarre editorial fashion model opening her eyes and lowering her gaze to the camera
